Background.text: Infection of extensor tendons rarely results in loculated infections, but disruption of normal flexor tendon function can be dangerous as it may spread proximally involving the wrist/forearm (Parona space). It is an surgical/orthopedic emergency!

Etiology.text:
Trauma with direct inoculation
Microbiology
"Clean trauma" - skin flora
Diabetes mellitus
, bites - Polymicrobial (gram -, anerobes)
Puncture from plants - Fungal (sporotrichosis)
Hematogenous spread
Microbiology
Gonorrhea
Look for vesiculopustular skin lesion, polyarthralgia
Mycobacteria
Contiguous spread

Clinical_Manifestations.text:
4 Kanavel signs:
(1) Finger held in slight flexion
(2) Fusiform swelling
(3) Tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath (late sign)
(4) Pain with passive extension of the digit (early sign)

Evaluation.text:
Labs: CBC, ESR/CRP, pre-op labs (T+S, coags, Chem-10)
X-Ray
Usually normal but helpful to rule out bony involvement, FB
Blood culture (if possible, obtain from synovial fluid)

Management.text:
Elevation of hand to help with swelling
Monitor clinically for hand compartment syndrome
Surgery/Ortho consult for wash-out vs. debridement

Antibiotics.text:
Treatment should cover
S. aureus
,
Streptococcus
, and
MRSA
Vancomycin
25-30 mg/kg IV loading dose then 15-20mg/kg IV q12hrs PLUS
Levofloxacin
750 mg IV once daily (avoid in pediatrics) OR
Ceftriaxone
1g IV daily
If suspicious of
Gonococcal
infection then use
Ceftriaxone
1g IV once daily AND
Chlamydia
coverage with
Azithromycin
1g PO once OR
Doxycycline
100mg PO twice daily

Pediatrics.text:
Ceftriaxone
100mg/kg IV once daily AND
Metronidazole
7.5mg/kg IV  four times daily OR
Clindamycin
10mg/kg IV four times daily NA
TMP/SMX
5mg/kg IV BID
Ampicillin/Sulbactam
50 mg/kg IV four times daily

Mycobacteria_related.text:
Treatment should include usual therapy listed above in addition to:
Clarithromycin
500mg PO twice daily PLUS
Ethambutol
15 mg/kg PO once daily OR
Rifampin
600 mg PO once daily
AND consult infectious disease
